title: Carenza Lewis
text:
Professor Carenza Rachel Lewis (born 30 November 1963) is a British academic <a href="archaeology">archaeologist</a> and television presenter.
Early life.
Lewis received her formal education at the school of the <a href="Church%20of%20England">Church of England</a> <a href="Community%20of%20All%20Hallows">Community of All Hallows</a>, in <a href="Suffolk">Suffolk</a>, and at <a href="Girton%20College">Girton College</a>, <a href="University%20of%20Cambridge">University of Cambridge</a>.
Field and academic career.
In 1985, she joined the <a href="Royal%20Commission%20on%20the%20Historical%20Monuments%20of%20England">Royal Commission on the Historical Monuments of England</a> as a field archaeologist for the <a href="Wessex">Wessex</a> area. During part of her time with the Commission she was seconded to the History Department of the <a href="University%20of%20Birmingham">University of Birmingham</a> to research the relationship between settlement and landscape in the <a href="East%20Midlands">East Midlands</a>. She followed this with a similar project in <a href="Hampshire">Hampshire</a> and the <a href="Isle%20of%20Wight">Isle of Wight</a>.
Lewis was elected a <a href="List%20of%20fellows%20of%20the%20Society%20of%20Antiquaries%20of%20London">Fellow of the Society of Antiquaries of London</a> in 1998. In 1999, she was elected a visiting fellow of <a href="Corpus%20Christi%20College%2C%20Cambridge">Corpus Christi College, Cambridge</a>, where she was a Senior Research Associate and Affiliated Lecturer. In 2004, she took on a new post at <a href="University%20of%20Cambridge">Cambridge</a> to promote undergraduate archaeology, and created "Access Cambridge Archaeology". In 2015, Lewis was appointed to the Professorial Chair of 'Public Understanding of Research' at the <a href="University%20of%20Lincoln">University of Lincoln</a>.
Television career.
In the early 1990s she joined the team presenting the "<a href="Time%20Team">Time Team</a>" series, a new television programme designed to make archaeology accessible for the general public, which was first broadcast on <a href="Channel%204%20Television">Channel 4 Television</a> in 1994. She appeared on the show from 1993 to 2005, appearing each season from the first through the twelfth. The <a href="audience%20measurement">ratings</a> success of the "Time Team" series led to further television presenting commissions for Lewis, including the series "House Detectives" (1997–2002).
In 2000, Lewis presented an episode of the <a href="British%20Broadcasting%20Corporation">BBC</a>'s theoretical history programme entitled "What If", where she examined the failed revolt of <a href="Boudicca">Queen Boudicca</a> and the <a href="Iceni">Iceni</a> against the Roman Empire in AD 60. She also devised and presented a series called "Sacred Sites" for <a href="ITV%20Wales%20%26amp%3B%20West">HTV</a>.
In 2010, she appeared in the television series "<a href="Michael%20Wood%27s%20Story%20of%20England">Michael Wood's Story of England</a>".
Personal life.
Lewis has three children. In 2000, she appeared in national print media detailing her experiences as one of a number of victims of medical misdiagnosis at the hands of Dr <a href="James%20Elwood">James Elwood</a> in the late 1990s.
